TitMainTitle: Portrait of Selma Burke posing with sculpture of bird, in interior, another version
CatDescriptText:
Cutline of image published in New Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 1, 1971, pg. 21, reads: "To Cite Famous Sculptor Amidst Fashions, Fantasy - Genius at Wirk [Work] - Dr. Selma H. Burke, whose artistic fingers fashion plaster, wood, marble, granite, alabaster and limestone into authentic life-size replicas of famous personalities or precious ornaments, is pictured putting the finishing touches on her latest creation. Many of her pieces are on exhibit at the Selma S. Burke Art Center, 6118 Penn Circle South, East Liberty. - Harris Photo."
Cutline of related image published in New Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, January 25, 1975, pg. 10, reads: "Dr. Selma Burke...artist at work." Accompanying article reads: "Carnegie Institute Museum Of Art Presents Selma Burke Sculpture - The Museum of Art, Carnegie Institute is presenting an exhibition of the work of Pittsburgh sculptor Selma Burke.  It began Friday, Jan. 17 and is extending through Sunday, Feb. 9.  Born in Mooresville, N. C., Selma Burke graduated from Columbia University in 1941, where her major interest was art, and she received a doctorate in Pedagogy from Teemers University, Charlotte, N. C.  She has studied sculpture under Reis, Malderelli [Maldarelli], Cornahani in New York, Mailloc in Paris and ceramics under Povolney in Vienna.  Actively involved in education throughout her life, she organized and directed the Greenwich Art School and served as an instructor at the Harlem Art Center in New York.  She was a consultant to the A. W. Mellon Foundation in Pittsburgh.. She is presently a member of the Pennsylvania Council on the Arts, Executive Director of the Selma Burke Art Center in Pittsburgh and works with the Pittsburgh Bard of Education through the Division of Education at Carnegie Institute.  She is Chairman of the Selma Burke Sculpture Award which is presented to students accomplished in painting and sculpture.  Selma Burke, who sculpts in a wide range of media and whose work has been termed 'classical' in concept, has exhibited at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts and in various city and university museums throughout the United States and Europe.  One-man exhibitions of the artist's work have been held at the Carlen Galleries, Philadelphia and at the Modernage Gallery and Artists Gallery, New York.  Sculpture by Selma Burke may be viewed in first floor gallery 21 Tuesday through Sunday from 10 until 5.  The Museum is closed Mondays."

TitMainTitle: Group portrait of artists William Palmer, Mrs. C. McKenzie Lewis, Thaddeus "Thad" Mosley, Mrs. John K. Tabor, Mrs. David M. Weill, and Mrs. Robert Freeman, posed with sculpture at Three Rivers Arts Festival, Gateway Center, Downtown
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 3, 1961, pg. 7, reads: "Art Festival Participants - Thousands are expected to attend the colorful and entertaining Pittsburgh Arts Festival, at the Gateway Center, June 2-7, daily until 10 P.M. The magnificent exhibit is being presenting by the Arts Festival Committee of Carnegie Institute. Admission is free.  Featured will be a symphony orchestra, painting, crafts, soloists, jazz, theatre, sculpture, architecture and folk singing.  Among the participants will be, left to right, front row: William Palmer, sculpture; Thaddeus Mosley, sculpture; Mrs. David M. Weill, exhibiting artist, who also will be in charge of arts and crafts demonstrations at the festival, and Mrs. Robert Freeman, program chairman of Music and Arts Club of Pittsburgh, and a Volunteers Day captain for the festival, on June 2 (opening night).  Back row: Mrs. C. McKenzie Lewis of the art exhibit committee and Mrs. John K. Tabor, chairman of the exhibit. - Harris Photo."

He was one of the six major winners whose entries will compete in the national exhibition at Carnegie Institute in May. The local exhibition, one of forty-three held annually across the country, will be shown at Kaufmann's Auditorium starting Feb. 23.  Mr. Saunders, who lives at 234 Burrows Street, is a student of Joseph Fitzpatrick. - Harris Photo.

TitMainTitle: Cab driver Alvin E. Grace covering face and walking through doorway marked "Docket Room," in Saw Mill Run Boulevard armory
CatDescriptText:
Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 12, 1956, pg. 15, reads: "'Don't' - Cab driver Alvin E. Grace, caught in the dope roundup, doesn't want the photographer to take his picture. - All photos by Harris."  
Portions of accompanying article by Frank Bolden read: "Biggest 'Haul' in Local Police History - Nab 150 in Big Dope Dragnet - We rendezvoused at 6 P.M., according to instructions.  Upon entering the huge armory on Saw Mill Run Boulevard, we met several old friends, including those from the identification department of the city Police Department and other newspaper friends.  All agreed that 'something's up,' and that 'something' was something BIG.  Of course, all knew.  But all had been sworn to secrecy.  Plans had been in the making for the past nine months and more.  After exchanging additional greetings, we were informed that if we wished, we could go nearby and have a 'bite to eat,' as we had the time.  With companions John Clark and 'Teenie' Harris of the Courier, I accepted the invitation, because it would probably ne many hours before we would have a chance to eat again..."  "Just before 9 P. M., after officers had been briefed, a mobilized force of more than 260 police officers - city, county, state and Federal - broken down into 15 squad, roared away from the armory, fanned out and began the search for the known dope addicts, 'pushers' and vagrants who were in the company of the former types of suspects..." "In Pittsburgh and Clairton agents carried 69 Federal warrants charging dope peddlers.  In additions, agents sought out addicts (users), 'junkies,' marijuana smokers and others in possession of barbiturates..."

TitMainTitle: William "Gus" Greenlee with his arm around woman wearing herringbone coat and head scarf, in booth at Crawford Grill No. 1
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, July 12, 1952, pg. 20, reads: "Everybody Liked 'Gus' - The ordinary people, the little folk, and the big ones with power and influence liked William A. (Gus) Greenlee, who died at his home here Monday after being ill for the past two years. Men, women and children displayed it in same manner that this customer at the now burned-out Crawford Grill is showing in this photo.  The folks on top remembered when 'Gus' helped them during the depression while they couldn't aid themselves.  The folks who weren't hitting it so well depended on him for many a touch.  That's how 'Gus' made and lost several fortunes...by 'being a friend to man.' - Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: New York Cubans baseball player with Homestead Grays baseball pitcher Ray Brown, at Forbes Field
CatDescriptText:
Cutline for image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, April 17, 1943, pg. 18, reads: "Grays Change Plans; Will Drill in Homestead - Key Men in Camp as Grays and Eagles Tune up for 1943 - As the Homestead Grays launched spring drills at West Field, Homestead, Pa., and the Newark Eagles opened their limbering-up sessions in Trenton, N.J., the three experts of the diamond pictured above were being counted on heavily as key men of the respective rosters... In 1943 the Grays will band heavily on the pitching production of Ray Brown, in lower photo, top fliuger [sic] in camp as the Grays started spring drills.  The talented Grays moundsman ranks with the best sepia hurlers of all times and anticipates turning in another good record in 1943." 

Image also published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, February 20, 1965, pg. 24, with headlines reading: "Heart Attack Fatal to Ex-Pitcher Ray Brown - Former Homestead Grays Ace, One of Games best Hurlers."

TitMainTitle: HIlda Laverne Logan modeling light colored short sleeved dress, walking down runway at Fashion Show Extravaganza in Sumpter Hall
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in New Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 5, 1973, pg. 9 reads: "Fashion Extravaganza - The Homewood-Brushton Community Improvement Associations, Inc., recently resented a Fashion Show Extravaganza at Sumpter Hall on Lincoln Avenue. The show featured the Frederick Models, Inc., with Mrs. Lorraine McCoad and Frederick Wims as commentators, Mrs. Gladys Howell was chairman and music was by Bill Gambrell.  Models are from left to right: Gerri Walker (Mrs. McCoad can be seen at microphone), Hilda Laverne Logan, Freddie Weaver, Pat White, and Carol Walls. - Harris photo."

TitMainTitle: Wanda Jackson, Mrs. John Hicks, Elmer Taylor, and police officer John Hicks, standing in hallway
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 18, 1949, p. 4, reads: "Accused Policemen Cleared by Trial Board -Officers' Wives Present...Picture above are Mrs. Karl C. [O.] Jackson, (left), Mrs. John Hicks, Elmer Taylor of Lee's Cleaners and officer Hicks.  Both wives seemed shy and retiring, but couldn't duck Courier cameraman, Tennie [Teenie] Harris, before picture was made. - Harris Photo."  Portion of accompanying article reads: "Clark Watts Denies Politics Influenced Filing of Charges - Witnesses of All Races Crowd Trial Room; Wait Throughout Five-Hour Session to Defend Character of Officers Jackson and Hicks - 'Big Brass' of the city's police department, headed by Col. George E. A. Fairley, director of public safety, heard a public airing. Wednesday, of charges that two Hill District police officers were 'aiding and abetting hoodlumism' against a legitimate businessman whom they had allegedly tried to force into the rackets.  The hearing, attended my more than fifty Herron Avenue district businessmen and citizens brought together for the first time Officers Karl C. [O.] Jackson and John Hicks, and their accuser, Clark Watts.  Mrs. Watts is the owner of the Watts' Brothers Cleaner Shop, 2931 Wylie Avenue, an establishment he claimed was coveted by the officers who wished to use it for illegal and illicit purposes..."

TitMainTitle: Demolition of Bethel AME Church with crane on left, Wylie Avenue and Elm Street, Hill District
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, July 27, 1957, pg. A8, reads: "'Mother Bethel' bows to progress... 'and the walls come tumbling down.'" Portion of accompanying article by B. H. Logan reads: "...We might weep over the demise of this old building, but the church itself will continue to shine brighter and brighter until that final day.  Bethel AME Church is the oldest Negro congregation in Pittsburgh or Allegheny County.  It has contributed thousands of dollars to Wilberforce University and other institutions of learning.  It has contributed to Christian missions both home and foreign.  The people of Pittsburgh should never forget this struggling congregation.  We should stop long enough to sing her praises to God...."

Williams, center, was ordained to the sacred order of the Priesthood in Episcopal Church recently, during rites held at Trinity Cathedral. High churchmen who participated in the ceremony, pictured left to right are: Canon Junius F. Carter, rector of the Church of the Holy Cross, the candidate's parish; Rev. Charles P. TitMainTitle: Reverend Harold Tolliver reading from book on lectern in Grace Memorial Presbyterian Church
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 25, 1949, pg. 11 reads: "Elect Rev. H.R. Tolliver Moderator of Presbytery - Plan Testimonial For Grace Pastor At Church June 30 - Portion of accompanying article reads: "One of the highest honors in Presbyterian Church was bestowed upon the Rev. Harold R. Tolliver, pastor at Grace Memorial Presbyterian Church, Tuesday when he was elected Moderator of the Presbytery of Pittsburgh.  He is the third Negro minister to head this second largest Presbytery in the Presbyterian Church, USA, and the first one in thirty years - Dr. M.B. Lanier, holding the honor first, and Dr. Charles H. Trusty being the second Negro chosen.  June 30, at 7:30 P.M., the officers, members and friends of Grace Memorial will honor the Rev. Mr. Tolliver with a testimonial banquet at the church, in appreciation of his eighteen years of ecclesiastical service at Grace."

TitMainTitle: Nedra Miller posing with her painting of John F. Kennedy with ribbon for second prize at 30th Allegheny County Fair, in her Beechview home with sunburst clock
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper October 7, 1967, pg. 13, reads: "Winner - Mrs. Nedra Mill of Beachview [Beechview], holds the painting of the late President Kennedy which won second prize for her at the recent County Fair.  A popular vote brought her to victory.  A young Beachview [sic] matron won second prize at the recent Allegheny County Fair with her painting of the late President John F. Kennedy.  Attractive Mrs. Nedra Miller of 1554 Napoleon Ave., has only been painting since 1964.  Always attracted to the arts, Mrs. Miller ventured first to the Arts and Crafts Center on Fifth Avenue, and was fortunate enough to study under Mary Shaw Marhonic.  Later, she learned the fine art of copying pictures as portraits on velvet, and worked at this for a time in conjunction with a studio.  Mrs. Miller's portrait of Kennedy won second prize by popular vote at the Fair.  Some day, she says, she will return to Arts and Crafts Center for further study. Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: Group portrait of Senator John F. Kennedy, Jackie Kennedy with closed eyes, congressman Thomas E. Morgan, and District Attorney Michael A. Hanna, in interior
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 17, 1959, page A2, reads: "U.S. Senator Visits - U.S. Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat, Massachusetts, who is considered by many to be a front runner for the Presidential nomination in 1960, was the principal speaker at a banquet and rally sponsored by the Washington County Democrats at the Twin Coaches in Belle Vernon last Friday night. Senator Kennedy rapped President Eisenhower for his action in the steel strike. The Senator is seated with on the left with his beautiful and charming wife. Standing, left to right: Congressman Thomas E. Morgan, who introduced the speaker, and Michael A. Hanna, District Attorney, who is seeking re-election. - Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: Men and women protesting with signs reading "Join the fight against segregation, join the fight for human rights," and "Make Woolworth serve everyone everywhere" outside Woolworth's, Smithfield Street and Sixth Avenue, Downtown
CatDescriptText: Cutline of related images published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, April 2, 1960, pg. 3 reads: "Picket Line Here Protests Dixie Bias - While a curious throng of onlookers, including some self-styled leaders of the fight for civil rights, watched with interest, approximately 80 men, women and youths threw an effective picket line around the downtown Woolworth store here, in protest against the chain company's acquiescence to the insulting segregation policy at its lunch counters in South...Among those unafraid to be counted in the picket line were Atty. Henry R. Smith, state president of the NAACP; Dr. Hugh Cleland, Pitt history professor; Peter D. Hammond, Pitt anthropology professor; the Revs. J.B. Cayce, Ebenezer Baptist Church; Churchill Carter, Park Place AME, Homestead; R. H. Reid, Payne Chapel AME, Duquesne, and J.G. Jarris, Bethel AME, Pittsburgh; Mrs. Marion B. Jordon, Mrs. Paul Knitt, James O. Dougan, Matthew Moore, Regis Bobonis, and The Courier's George E. Barbour and Frank E. Bolden. - Harris Photos

CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, December 28, 1957, pg. 1 reads: "Million-Dollar Fire - Rankin police keep order as firemen direct water on a blazing house which had been occupied by the Anderson Harries, John Hackley, Mr. and Mrs. Albert Finney and another family, on Second St., Rankin, area of the most extensive damage. The big affair will be held at the Elks Lodge No. 17, at 81 Fullerton street.  There will be dancing from 12 midnight to 6 a. m. Alston; Chairman, Edward English; Grant Bolden, Lemuel Nixon, Raymond Johnson, Edgar Parker and George (Buss) Christian.  Music will be furnished by Neeny Waters and his orchestra."

TitMainTitle: Police officers loading body of murder victim George Howard into ambulance, near his apartment at 708 Junilla Street, Hill District
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, November 24, 1951, pg. 1, reads: "Brutal Murder Draws Crowd - A crowd of several hundred persons gathered soon after word of the brutal slaying of 100-year-old George Howard in bed of his basement apartment at 708 Junilla Street, last Wednesday or Thursday, spread through the Hill District. The aged pensioner was bludgeoned to death either by a thief or thieves or someone intent on wreaking vengeance on him, homicide detectives believe.  The victim was found by an ice man when the latter stopped to deliver Howard's regular order of ice around noon Thursday.  The Courier photographer was on the scene to bring Courier readers a short pictorial story of events as they transpired.  Left to right: ...(3) Police, detectives and morgue attendants place the canvas wrapped body of the murdered man in a police ambulance as the human cordon parts ranks and looks on, with a mixture of curiosity, sadness and fright... - Harris Photos."

TitMainTitle: Brick wall of Pittsburgh Railways Company Shops with graffiti reading "Dirty White Folk," "White Ass," and "Poor White Hunky Bitch," Homewood and Frankstown Avenues, Homewood
CatDescriptText: Cutline of images published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 13, 1955, pg. 15, reads: "What's Happening on Homewood Ave.? Does This Portend A New 'Hill District'? For more than fifty years a peaceful, interracial community, in recent years the Homewood-Brushton District has been gradually shifting; becoming more and more the home of Negro families.  In recent months, with the announcement that the better part of at least seven blocks occupied by white rental tenants was being sold to Negroes by one real estate company alone, complaints began to reach The Courier as to the manner in which white families were being put out of the homes bought by Negroes and from Negro families about the high prices and terms of sale of many real estate outfits selling homes.  That all is not exactly calm in Homewood-Brushton area is reflected by the writings on two sides of a pillar of the Pittsburgh Railways Company Shops at the main corner of Homewood-Brushton, Homewood and Frankstown Avenues, where Frankstown Avenue and Ardmore trolley riders transfer to the Homewood-Penn Township and Squirrel Hill bus.  The pictures at the top of this page show both sides of the same pillar.  The side carrying words derogatory to and hated by Negroes appeared first.  Then the side of the pillar carrying racial epithets sometimes hurled at whites appeared as a sort of answer.  Another indication that the community balance is being shifted towards Negroes is the seven or eight stores on Homewood Avenue that are vacant or which bear signs that they are moving to other neighborhoods in a period in which Pittsburgh's businessmen are going through one of the biggest eras of prosperity ever to hit the city.  Yet stores which formerly catered to more whites than Negroes are moving.  All of the stores pictured here have moved or are going to move.  A white funeral parlor at the corner of Race Street and Homewood Avenue which moved Aug. 1 is not pictured.  This could have been added to the many moving to other sections.  If city-wide prosperity does not make business stay on Homewood Avenue, then the state of business on Homewood Avenue does not make them leave either.  It must be something else.  One business leader says: 'Most of the businessmen of Homewood Avenue welcome the influx of Negroes into the community.  Doubling up by Negroes in order to pay high prices for single family homes, swells the population of the community, and as a result they supermarkets and other stores are packed to the doors daily with customers.'"
CatSubject_tab:
Brick walls--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh.
Graffiti--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh.

TitMainTitle: Boxer "Jersey" Joe Walcott with baby on lap getting haircut from barber Clarence "Speedy" Williams in Crystal Barber Shop
CatDescriptText:
The Crystal Barber Shop and Billiard Parlor was owned by Woogie Harris.
Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, July 28, 1951, page 2, reads: "Detectives Guard Champ's Haircut - When the new heavyweight champion, Jersey Joe Walcott, stopped off at "Woogie" Harris' Crystal Barber Shop on Wylie Avenue last Thursday to get a haircut after his knockout of Ezzard Charles, the previous night, the crowd that wanted to get a look at Walcott were so thick police had to protect him from his admirers. Here Detectives Eugene Parker, James Voyle Parker and John B. Thompson, who acted as bodyguards for Walcott while he was here, wait for the new champ to get his hair clipped by barber "Speedy" Williams. - Harris Photo"

TitMainTitle: Soldiers in parade formation marching on street at intersection of Centre Avenue, in front of Thomas DeLuxe Ice Cream Bar, Centre Builders' Supply, Fifth Ward Honor Roll, and A. Leo Weil School, for fourth of July celebration by Soho Community Association, Centre Avenue, Hill District
CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, July 7, 1945, pg. 13, reads: "Our Boys - At Ease! - Members of the 4000th AAF Base Unit with sixty six-foot soldiers in full battle dress stand at ease while a throng of 10,000 persons who attended the Soho Community Association's Independence Day program listen to speakers at A. Leo Weil School in front of the Service Honor Roll. With the four captains from the 4000th AAF Base Unit added to the names of Capts. Charles Hall and William Thompson, a total of six captains were present.  Eleven Gold Star Mothers, a member of wounded Deshon Hospital veterans, outstanding political figures, national and local, were present.  Among other groups that participated were: Mounted Police, Indiantown Gap Band, National Guard Unit and Band, Drum and Bugle Corps (five), Forty-and-Eight, American Legion, Veterans of Foreign Wars, Auxiliary Police, Red Cross, and Elks Lodges.  These organizations had just completed a parade through the Hill District."

TitMainTitle: Mal Goode, and woman posing beside Dodge car, at 1959 Pittsburgh Courier Home Service Fair, Syria Mosque
CatDescriptText: Cutline of related images published in New Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 6, 1959, pg. 6, 7, reads: "'A Home Show Named Success' must be the appropriate label tagged to the ninth annual Courier Home Service Fair, held at the massive Syria Mosque, last Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday nights. This will be the most talked about 'Fair' ever.  From the opening night when thousands began to gather at the doors, to the final session, when the laughter of prize winners waved emotionally with the disappointed non-winners, the exhibitors and participants worked enthusiastically from their national and local booths to accommodate the happy homemakers.  Beautifully decorated booths, sweet organ music augmented by the 'rock 'em, sock 'em' jazz of Sarah McLawler's combo, set the mood for the huge audiences... - Harris Photos."

Center: Personality plus was exhibited by Sylvia Yvonne Davis Tuesday night as she modeled her smart riding habit with all the poise of an adult.  She was one of the many petite models who appeared in the Beauty Shop Owner's Review.  Right: Mrs. Pocahontas Crews turned on her glamour too, Tuesday night.  Stunning in every scene, she was positively breath-taking in this evening gown, as you can see for yourself. TitMainTitle: State liquor store clerks Lillian Asaf and Charles Coleman behind counter, in state store with advertisement for March of Dimes, Sixth and Wylie Avenues
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper February 1, 1947, pg. 14, reads: "Ain't Nobody Here But Us 'Spirits' - Liquor store employes [employees] got a little rest Monday, the first day of 'no ration' liquor sales. For long periods of time nary a customer entered the emporium for a spot of the stuff which made the late John Barrymore and W. C. Fields famous. Shelves were full of whiskey, gin, rum and wine, but takers were few and far between. The top photo is a scene at the State store at Sixth and Wylie Avenues showing clerks Lillian Asaf and Charles Coleman... Some customers ignore the end of liquor rationing Monday giving State store clerks a chance to catch up on paper work. - Harris Photo." [Accompanying image is of lines at grocery store of people buying butter instead.]

TitMainTitle: Julian Black, Mrs. Black, Blanche Morris, Eve Lynn Reynolds, and Mr. Reynolds, standing on pier for christening ceremony for SS Robert L. Vann, Portland, Maine
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, national edition, October 16, 1943, pg. 20 reads: "Guests Add Color To Pre- Launching Activities, Christening Ceremony For SS Robert L. Vann - Spaulding Lauds Vann - Portland, Me - 'Nowhere on earth could such an occasion as we are witnessing here today occur but in our own America,' asserted C.C. Spaulding, president of the North Carolina Mutual Life Insurance company in Durham, largest all-Negro business in world, as he delivered the principal speech Sunday at the launching here of the Liberty ship, 'S.S. Robert L. Vann' in memory of the late lawyer, politician, humanitarian, and publisher under whose leadership The Pittsburgh Courier became the biggest and most influential Negro newspaper, extant. 'The launching of the Robert L. Vann - sixth Liberty ship to be named for an outstanding Negro - marks another epoch in the annals of American history.' Mr. Spaulding said.  Robert L. Vann was a leader, a statesman, an organizer a publisher of note, and my personal friend,' the insurance magnate continued.  'I repeat that he was such an organizer that The Courier, which he edited and controlled for 30 years, has been so successfully managed since his passing that the circulation has been increased from 170,000 to 255,000 under the leadership of his comrade and successor, Ira F. Lewis, and his devoted companion, Mrs. Robert L. Vann, who stood so nobly by the late humanitarian during his brilliant career.  'Both his ideas and ideals will be carried forward by this, the S.S. Robert L. Vann, as it plows the sea, as well as by his successors in the great Courier family.  The naming of the six ships for outstanding Negroes has done more to inspire and encourage Negro Americans than any other act of the National Maritime commission.  My congratulations and God bless you all.'  From all walks of life came prominent figures to attend the testimonial luncheon at the Lafayette Hotel and the christening ceremony for the Liberty ship 'S.S. Robert L. Vann,' Sunday in the New England shipbuilding yards in South Portland, Maine...Extreme right center, another launching group showing Julian Black, Mrs. Julian Black and Mrs. Blanche Morris, all of Chicago; Mrs. Eve Lynn Reynolds, Courier columnist, and Hobe [illegible] Reynolds, prominent undertaker, both of Philadelphia."
CatSubject_tab:

TitMainTitle: Democrat K. Leroy Irvis and Republican David Thompkins, candidates for State Legislature in First Legislative District, standing in front of Fifth Ward's 18th District polling place, Hill District
CatDescriptText:
Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, November 8, 1958, pg. 4, reads: "Opponents at Polls - These two opposing candidates for the State Legislature in First Legislative District are shown in from front the Fifth Ward's 18th District polling place, Tuesday afternoon. Republican David Thompkins, right, wanted to congratulate his opponent, but Democrat K. Leroy Irvis, left, declined, stating: 'Let's wait and see what the returns show.' Mr. Irvis Won. - Harris Photo."

The slate of candidates on the campaign posters reads: "Pennsylvania First, Vote For Democratic Candidates; For U.S. Senator - George M. Leader, Judge of the Supreme Court - Curtis Bok, For Governor - D. L. Lawrence, Lieutenant Governor - Morgan Davis, Secretary of Internal Affairs - Genieve[?] Blatt, Representative in Congress - 28th District - William S. Moorehead, [?]ve in the General Assembly - 1st District, K. Leroy Irvis, James F. Clark.  Another poster reads: "Elect this Slate in '58; Hugh Scott - For U.S. Senator,  Arthur T. McGonigle - For Governor, [?]Walker, Lieutenant Governor, [?] Gleason, Secretary of Internal Affairs, [?] Woodside, Judge of Supreme Court". The last poster reads: "Give Yourself a Tax Break;  Representative in Congress - Harry L. Verbofsky, Representative in General Assembly - W.A Miller, [?]Thompkins".

TitMainTitle: Vincent "Roots' Wilson protesting in front of Allegheny County Courthouse with placard reading "Where is justice for the Negro - Heard gets 9 to 18 mos. White - McBeth goes free"
CatDescriptText:
Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 7, 1966, pg. 1A, reads: "Lone Protester - Vince Wilson of the Hill District was on hand at the City-County Building Monday protesting the sentencing of former city policeman Robert Heard to a 9 to 18 month jail term, while Robert McBeth, a white city policeman went free on charges for killing a Negro fleeing a dice game. Many others in Negro community have expressed indignation over Heard's conviction...Harris Photo." 

Portion of related article published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 7, 1966, pg. 1A, reads: "Even though a Criminal Court panel of three judges ruled within the past month that a white patrolman, Robert McBeth, cannot even be tried on the involuntary manslaughter count in the accidental shooting of a Negro fleeing and open-air dice game, another Criminal Court Judge Robert Van der Voort last week sentenced ex-policeman, Robert Head, a Negro, to serve 9-18 months in the workhouse for accidentally shooting to death a white man while quelling a restaurant disturbance..."

TitMainTitle: Men, women, one wearing leaf patterned dress, and children seated at banquet tables in Rodman Baptist Church for 80th Anniversary party
CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in New Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 22, 1965, pg. 14 reads: "Rodman Cites 50-Year Members - The closing feature of the 80th anniversary observance at Rodman Street Baptist Church, recently, was a banquet honoring members who had been faithful to the church for a half century or more. Active participants were (seated center) Rudolph Jeffries, speaker; Mrs. and the Rev. G.L. Bowick, Joseph Manker, toastmaster, and Linwood Gaskins, general chairman.  The honorees, looking none the worse for the years, were (seated, beginning left) Mmes. Lillie Yuille, Mary Gordon, Blanche Martin, Mary Gould, Ruth White, Ada Thurston, Maggie Edmonds, Ethel Senior, Mabel Stewart and Margaret Paxton.  Standing: Mrs. L. Bondurant, Mrs. M. Gibson, Mrs... Saunders, Mrs. F. Carroll, John Covington, Mmes. E. Watkins, M. Thomas, F. Woods, Lillian Loving, Mrs. Edna Mayo, Mmes. H. Brown, M. Redman and Sarah Smith.  Mr. and Mrs. William Frederick (back row second from right) were among the guests present.  honorees at this level are John Thomas (right), George Diggs.  Mrs. Estelle Allen and William Watson, left - Harris Photo."

Shown here are several models and their intriguing hair-do's.  Top row, left to right: Rochelle Robinson wearing 'The Hill Top Tower'; June Rodgers and the mahd [mad] 'Flower Basket'; Hattie Knox shows how Golden Haze over a permanent can be 'Soft and Sophisticated'; elegant Ann Perry is just right for an evening at a formal dance.  Lower photos, left to right; Mrs. Delores Sledge wears three Fastenfast hair pieces for the 'Discotheque Look'; the 'Pre-Teen Pony Lift' is modeled by young Paulette Silvers; Beraline Crawford models 'Eastern Accent' and  last, Sandra Taylor wears one long all-over wig for the 'Free and Easy' style. - Harris Photos."

CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, March 3, 1956, pg. 31, reads: "Fifth Meets Oliver for Crown - After Oliver - There was plenty of jubilation at Allderdice High School by these Fifth Avenue players Tuesday afternoon after they had defeated Westinghouse to win the championship in Section One of the city basketball race and qualify to play Oliver at Pitt Stadium Friday night. Preparation of a well-balanced meal may soon become an impossibility for the suffering housewives.  Awaiting this "last round-up" meal are (left to right): Herbert, 3, Paul, 8, Mr. and Mrs. Newell, Louise, 5, and Bertha, 6.  Many families expect a long strike. - Harris Photo."

CatDescriptText:
Cutline of image published in New Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, December 6, 1969, pg. 6 "Organize Black Catholic Knights - Officers of Council 157, Knights of St. Peter Claver, which was organized at St. Brigid's-St. Benedict The Moor Church on a recent Sunday morning, and those who conducted the Installation Rites are pictured above.  Among those in the left photo, reading from left are: Bill Long, trustee of the new council; Leo Evans, inner guard; Dr. Earl Belle Smith, fourth degree Knight of St. Gregory; Father John LaBauve, now of Louisiana, assistant National Chaplain; Martin Davis, treasurer; Willie Kelley of Chicago, Ill., district deputy of Northern States; Msgr. Paul Bassompierre, pastor; Shields Gilmore, of New Orleans, La., National Supreme Knight and Franklin Jerry of Pittsburgh, Grand Knight of the newly organized council...-Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: Folding screen decorated with stamps, Abraham Lincoln statue, Statue of Liberty, and fighter planes, created by Frank S. Spangler for Pittsburgh Press Golden Age Hobby Show
CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 8, 1955, pg. 6 reads: "Golden Age Hobbyists - The third annual Golden Age Hobby Show and Sale, sponsored by the Health and Welfare Federation of Allegheny County and the Pittsburgh Press, was held form Sept. 29 to Oct. 3 at the Arts and Crafts Center, 6300 Fifth Avenue. Among the hobbyists who personified the saying that "a hobby is a symbol  of something made for pure joy" were...Mr. Spangler's screen containing about 7,000 stamps, is seen in left photo...Other entrants, not shown, were Mrs. Cornelia Young, of the Lemington Avenue Home, who although partially blind, crocheted a rug, and John Writt, 80, who fabricated a "mobile," a hanging collection of suspended card board figures, and painted several pictures as his entries.  The Social Service Department of the Mount Lebanon Women's Club, Mrs. Donald O. Northrup, chairman, on Thursday, gave a reception at the Arts and Crafts Center for the exhibitors. Some visitors to the hobby show were greatly impressed by he various entries and especially those of "Miss Dolly" after they learned of the hobbyist's age and viewed the exacting work that required patience and nimble fingers.  "I worked on my entries, the child's dress and the cocktail apron of black net, and did not show them to anybody until they were finished," Miss Dolly, twice a blue-ribbon winner, said.  Mrs. Williams, who said she first started making quilts as a "really young girl" in Rome, Ga., also entered an Eastern Star Handkerchief...-Harris PHotos."
CatSubject_tab:

TitMainTitle: Wedding party members, including from left: Beatrice Williams, Kathryn Bolden, unknown, Bill Carter, Marty Sloan, Harry Bobo, and Herbert Douglass, standing underneath awning in front of Holy Cross Church for Williams - Brice wedding
CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, National Edition, July 18, 1942, pg. 8 reads: "The Wedding Of The Year...Pittsburgh has never witnessed a prettier wedding ceremony and reception than the rites held for Miss Minerva Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Williams and John Edwin Brice, son of Mrs. Robert Turnbull, all of Pittsburgh. Shown at the reception are the parents of the bride, Mrs. Williams wore a gown of black marquisette with bands of real lace over a pink satin slip.  Mr. Williams, one of Pittsburgh's most successful businessmen, is shown with his lovely wife in top left photo.  Center, the bride, Mrs. John Edwin Brice (nee Minerva Williams).  Her veil of illusion is caught with a real orchid.  At right: The bridal party.  The girls are, left to right: Frances Moore, Kathryn Bolden, Beatrice Williams, sister of the bride and maid of honor; Mary McNeal, cousin of the bride, and Suzanne Patterson.  The men, left to right: Harry Bobo, outstanding heavyweight king of Pittsburgh, who was the best man, Mar[t]y Sloan, Herbert Douglass, and Bill Carter.  The newlyweds are shown at right, in beautifully decorated Loendi Club, where the reception was held  last Tuesday evening, following the wedding ceremony at the Church of the Holy Cross.  They have returned from a honeymoon trip in Cleveland, Ohio. - Harris Photos."

CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 27, 1962, pg. 4 reads: "Prince Hall Shriners Plan Confab - Prince Hall Shriners will hold their 62nd national convention in Pittsburgh, beginning Aug. 18, 1963. Officials of the fraternal group met in a three-day session in the Steel City recently and mapped elaborate plans for what is expected to be the largest convention in many years.  Attending the meeting, in the Penn-Sheraton Hotel, were, left to right, seated: Waynard H. Jones of Detroit, Mich., convention director; M.C. Martin, Danville, Va., treasurer; Atty. Genoa S. Washington, Chicago, Ill., Imperial Potentate; Thomas F. Poag, Winston-Salem, N.C., Deputy Imperial Potentate, and Booker T. Alexander, Detroit, recorder.  Standing: Henry M. Baysmore, Philadelphia, Pa., M.W. Grand Master, Prince Hall Lodge of Pennsylvania; Harry J. Keen, Pittsburgh, 1963 co-chairman of the convention committee; Marshall S. Johnson, Pittsburgh, 1963 convention coordinator, and John R. Bradford, Pittsburgh, 1963 convention committee secretary. - Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: Interior with bedroom on right, and bathroom with stalls on left, in Harriet Tubman Terrace House, 7921 Frankstown Avenue
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 21, 1950, pg. 23, reads: "New Harriet Tubman Terrace House...for convalescent Ne...women...This beautiful home for shut-ins, located at 7921 Frankstown Avenue near Oakwood Street, will be rededicated Sunday, Oct. 29...house will be held that day from 10 A.M. until 6 P.M. with special...at 3 P.M. in form of a 'Greenback Shower.' At the ceremony plaques will be unveiled honoring Mrs. Abraham Lincoln president and Mrs. John M. Phillips, honorary president, and Mrs. H.C. McEl...the guild's 'fairy' godmother.  Judge Homer S. Brown will dedicate...plaques.  Judge Lois McBride will be mistress of ceremonies, and Mrs. Daisy L. Lampkin will respond to the welcome address.  Pictured are some of the remodeled views of the Convalescent Home which tell own story...a bird's eye view of the new powder room and the newly furnished bedroom...Mrs. Calvin Bartlett is president, Mrs. Golden May, chairman of the building committee, and Mrs. Preston Clayton, chairman of endowment.  The home can be reached by cars 88 or 87. - Harris Photos."

Center (2001.35.24877), the handsome array of bridal attendants pretty in pastels, surround the happy bride whose Chantilly lace and nylon net gown was a masterpiece of beauty.  Right, Harry Waugh, Calvert Western Pennsylvania sales representative, presents the gift of a ten-day expense-paid honeymoon to the couple for the Hotel Calvert in Miami, Fla. - Harris Photos."

The Rev. Dr. T. J. King, pastor of the Ebenezer Baptist performed the impressive double-ring ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.  Wears Orchid - The bride wore a deep orchid colored dress with pink accessories and an orchid corsage.  She carried a white prayer book.  The bride's sister, her only attendant, wore a gray satin dress and a corsage of red roses.  Dr. M. Ronald Williams of Los Angeles, Calif., was best man..."

TitMainTitle: Portrait of Mary Drew, wearing striped two piece bathing suit, leaning against ladder of Ammon Recreation Center swimming pool
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 3, 1946 reads: "A Bathing Beauty - A perfect example of an honest-to-goodness bathing beauty, Mary Drew, one of Pittsburgh's most able "aqua girls," will be among the participants in colorful Water Circus at Ammon Center pool Friday, Aug. 9. The Circus, directed by Pomeroyal C. Fountain, physical education instructor of the Centre Avenue YMCA, will be one of the feature events of Frogs Week Celebration.  Lovelies from all over Western Pennsylvania will vie for top honors in the bathing beauty contest.  The winner will be awarded a $50 was bond, and other cash prizes will be given to those sharing honors.  The spectacular show will include all types of stunts, ballet dancing and thrilling diving.  The Bureau of Recreation is joining with the Frogs in sponsoring the Circus which promises to be as sensational as anything of its kind ever presented here.  According to the committee in charge of the event a large crowd is expected. - Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: Man, possibly Congressman Arthur W. Mitchell standing on porch of his estate, Dinwiddie County, Virginia
CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, November 28, 1942, pg. 8, reads:  "Mitchell Will Retire to Historic VA. Estate: The Courier Gets Another Exclusive: First Published Photographs of the Virginia Estate of the Mitchells - Pictured above are the first published photographs of the Virginia home of Congressman and Mrs. Arthur W. Mitchell, the estate to which he will retire in January.  The estate comprises 28 acres, with a 14-room colonial mansion, with three baths, and a $7,000 flower garden.  These photos, taken by Courier Staff Photographer Charles Harris, show the Mitchell home in three different shots, with a view of the shrubbery, the walks, and the distinctive architectural design.  The Mitchell gateway, an unusual 'shot' taken from the bedroom of the mansion, and the Congressman (in working clothes) standing in the center of Magnolia Lane are also shown."

TitMainTitle: Four women and eight children, including two boys on right wearing dark shorts, posed in yard next to school building
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, July 5, 1941, pg. 3, reads: "These Youths Will Lose Out When WPA Cuts Curtail Supervised Play Here - Children like those in top picture will lose their supervised play periods when the July 3rd WPA cut releases over 1500 Community Service workers including many playground and recreational experts. Adolescent girls like the volley-ball players shown at the bottom, left, will be thrown back into slum streets for recreation at the very age when health and strength contribute so much to a happy womanhood.  Scientifically supervised athletics, however, are decreed by Congress to be luxuries in this time of National Defense, even if the rising generation must play in the streets.  The picture at the right reveals the interest parents show in the clean safe and pleasant playgrounds where their smaller children are carefully guarded and supervised, secure from traffic dangers which statistics prove to be greatest in congested residential districts and where many children must somehow find an outlet.  Pittsburgh parents had hoped for an increase in supervised recreation rather than this curtailment, which they fear will further expose their youngsters to the evils and dangers of dirty, traffic-crowded streets and alleys. - Harris photo."

TitMainTitle: Arthur Harris, Major Ponder, Grace Smith, and Peter Hotzidais or Hatzidais, standing before Alderman Harris Fitzgerald, another version
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, November 6, 1948, pg. 5, reads: "Arthur Harris, Major Ponder, Grace Smith, Peter Hotzidais, Squire Fitzgerald." Accompanying article reads: "Color Line a Custom, Waitress Tells Squire - Two members of the Sons of Harmony Quartet who sing over Station WHOD, Homestead, testified in Alderman Fitzgerald's court Thursday that a waitress at the K. and H. Sandwich Shop, 806 Amity Street, Homestead, refused them service with the excuse that 'she was afraid the boss would fire her.'  The waitress, Grace Smith, 32, 5475 Hillcrest Street, tearfully pleaded guilty of refusing the two men, by said that she had received no instructions from the proprietor, Peter Hatzidais, to do so.  'She Refused on Her Own'  At the hearing, Mr. Hatzidais repeated in testimony what Alderman Fitzgerald said Hatzidais had told him in a telephone conversation several days before the trial: 'I serve everybody in my restaurant and always have.  If she refused these men service, she did it on her own initiative and I don't have any sympathy for her.  She'll take her own consequences, I make my own roles as to policy in my restaurant and discrimination has never been one of my regulations.  Miss Smith had that she had only worked ten weeks at the restaurant, that she had been employed before that by Dempsey and Rand's restaurant, Sheridan Avenue, East Liberty, and that there she was not permitted to serve Negroes upon threat of loss of her job.  She said she had been a waitress for twelve years and had found a similar policy on other jobs.  Alderman Fitzgerald asked the youths if they were willing to withdraw the case upon payment of the costs by Hatzidais and Miss Smith, which was done.  Alderman Fitzgerald said that he had received several telephone calls from Homestead business men about...[illegible] Arthur Harris, 2[?]31 Centre Avenue, and Major Ponder, 1814 Enoch Street, brought the suit."

Shouts Vernon As Conference Blasts Hopes - Delegates Deaf to Eloquent Plea of Former Leader in Church - Episcopal Committee Firm for Retirement, but Refuses to Pass on Character. - FLASH! No Appeal for Vernon! - Detroit, Mich., May 9 - In a heated battle on the Conference...Monday morning. Bishop W.T. Vernon lost his last chance to appeal the decision of the body made Saturday when his reinstatement...active bishop was refused.  The vote to reconsider was...against."  Portion of accompanying article by Julia B. Jones reads: "Detroit, May 9 - A torrent of "ayes" and "Nays" burst forth here Saturday morning when the all-powerful Episcopal Committee, in its first report to the Assembly, recommended that Bishop W.T. Vernon of Kansas remain...the retired list..."

CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper January 18, 1947, pg. 2, reads: "Guilty? - Students of McKelvey School conduct one of their Traffic Court sessions which have been mainly responsible for the lack of accidents in Miller School, according to Dr. Louis Kalassey, principal. Intelligent instruction in the rules of traffic and precautionary measures has resulted in Miller School winning the green safety pennant. The children conduct the court with regular courtroom procedure and every legal angle is rigidly observed. The school has been including the Traffic Court in its curriculum since October. - Harris Photo."

CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, February 1, 1941, pg. 8, reads: "When lovely Ruth Goode became the bride of William White last Friday afternoon, the sartorial perfection was in order. Portions of article read: "Ruth Goode, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Goode, became the bride of Ralph Warner White, son of Mrs. Mamie White of Keystone, W. Va., on Friday afternoon in Clark Memorial Baptist Church.  Rev. E. P. Tunie performed the ceremony....The couple will reside at 1002 Blackadore Street, Homewood.  Mr. and Mrs. White are graduates of West Virginia State College..."

TitMainTitle: Men, including one on right wearing overcoat, and women, gathered around tables in Norse Room in Fort Pitt Hotel for hotel employee Christmas party
CatDescriptText: Cutline of related images published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, December 20, 1941, pg. 24, reads: "FORT PITT YULETIDE PARTY IN NORSE ROOM GIVEN FOR NEGRO WORKERS - Leroy Brown and his orchestra provided the music and William Harris, manager of the Fort Pitt Hotel, gave brief remarks during the annual Christmas banquet and dance for the hotel's race workers. The 1941 version of the affair was one of the best to date.  Top left photo shows one of the guest tables.  Seated are: Mr.and Mrs. Robert Donell, Mrs. Roosevelt Gloster, Roosevelt Gloster, Banquet Captain, and one of the hosts of the party, Charles Porter, James Hays, entertainer, who with Billy Alston as Emcee, put on a comical skit.  The lower left photo shows the hosts for the evening of gaiety, left to right, Andrew Fulton, lounge bar captain; Clarence Bruce, head waiter, and Roosevelt Gloster, banquet captain.  The right picture shows more of the guests and employees. Left to right are: Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Bruce, Mr. and Mrs. Othur Taylor, and C.E. Bruce and company. - (Harris photo). "

CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 21, 1950, pg. 1, reads: "Dr. Ralph Bunche Honored - Because of the heavy demand by library patrons for information concerning Dr. Ralph Bunche, Nobel Peace Prize winner for 1950, Carnegie Library recently erected a literary exhibit in honor of the distinguished career diplomat. Left to right: The Misses Leon Reis and Helen Tolliver, library clerks, view a series of articles about Dr. Bunche's, historic work at Rhodes, Dodecanese Islands, which were written by pg. L. Prattis, executive editor of The Courier, who was the only journalist present at Rhodes during the sessions.  The Courier donated the articles to the exhibit. - Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: Pete Sharp and Sol Jones working on foundation of house at construction site, with piles of cinder block and trees in background, possibly East End
CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 9, 1953, pg. 32, reads: "E. L. Smith, Builder, From Blueprint To New Community - New Homes Are News - Few Pittsburgh Negroes have ever had the privilege of living in a new home. Within recent years, E. L. Smith has built more new homes for Negroes than any other local building contractor. Operating principally on the East End - Penn Township sector, he has sparked the emergence of a new community in this area.  Here our photographer has taken pictures of phases of the Smith operation, as he converts raw land into a setting for graceful living. - Harris Photos."  "Down to Rock - There is no more vital part of a house than its foundation.  Here Pete Sharp and Sol Jones set one."

TitMainTitle: Joseph Givens, Walter C. Beckett, George H. Gould, Dr. Raymond E. Jackson, Henry D. Horner, Clarence C. Kittrell, and unknown standing behind banquet table, with others seated beside them including Julia Gaines third from left, William W. Grasty, John R. Bradford, Harry M. Montgomery, Henry M. Baysmore, Wilbur Douglass, Edward T. Bowser, Mayor David L. Lawrence, and others gathered for Masonic event at Syria Mosque
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 17, 1953, page 20, reads: "Masonic Banquet Marks 'Prince Hall Day' - The Seventh Masonic District of Prince Hall Masons last Saturday at Syria Mosque feted delegates from other districts throughout the state, grated a plaque posthumously to Mrs. Julia Gaines, wife of the late Grand Master George W. Gaines, who died recently, and other plaques to former Past Grand Masters now living. Dr. Raymond E. Jackson, 33*, Imperial Potentate of the Ancient Egyptian Arabic Order of Nobles of the Mystic Shrine, shown standing in the center, was the main speaker. Standing behind him are the living Past Grand Masters who were honored. Left to right: Atty. Joseph Givens, 1945-46; Walter C. Beckett, 1923-33; George H. Gould, 1949-37, and Clarence C. Kittrell, 1923-24. Seated, from far left to far right, are: Mrs. Julia Gaines, who received the award posthumously for her late husband; William W. Grasty, Right Worshipful Deputy Grand Master and acting Grand Master, who was presented a hand-printed 'Scroll of Confidence and Respect from the District from District Deputy John R. Bradford, seated next to him; Hon. Harry M. Montgomery, judge of the Common Pleas Court; Henry M. Baysmore, State Grand Lecturer; Atty. Wilbur Douglass, Right Worshipful Grand Attorney; Edward T. Bowser, Past Grand Master of New Jersey, and David L. Lawrence, Mayor of the City of Pittsburgh, who brought greetings to the diners, on 'Prince Hall Day,' which he officially proclaimed. Also on hand were the following visiting Grand Masters: Walter C. Beckett of Philadelphia; Henry D. Horner of Philadelphia, and Clarence Kittrell of Erie. - Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: Majorettes of the North Side Elks, acting as pallbearers, carrying two small caskets from Grace Memorial Presbyterian Church, for funeral of fire victims Clarence Gary Hart, Phyllis Chambers, and Terry English
CatDescriptText:
Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, January 30, 1954, pg. 17 reads: "Crowds Mourn Death of Young Fire Victims - Last Rites - Funeral services for the three children, who died in a gas-blast fire at 9 Kearney Way, shortly after midnight last Wednesday, were held in Grace Memorial Presbyterian Church, Monday afternoon. It was a sad occasion as family, relatives and other members of the community mourned the tragedy which cast such a pall over the Hill District.  Upper center, majorettes of the North Side Elks, who served as pall bearers and flower girls, carry the casket of one of the victims..."

Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, January 30, 1954, pg. 1, reads: "Attend Funeral - Nurses for St. John Hospital, where Miss Marion Hart, 19, formerly of 9 Kearney Way, is a student, attended the funeral of Miss Hart's brother and two nieces Monday at Grace Memorial Presbyterian Church.  The youngsters were victims of the gas-blast fire which killed four and injured three last week at the aforementioned address.  The tragedy shocked the Hill District. - Harris Photo."  Portions of article read: "...three children who lost their lives in a searing, gas-fed fire at 9 Kearney Way shortly after midnight last Wednesday.  Four others were injured in same holocaust, two of them critically....And early Wednesday morning, Fate decreed that one of those critically injured should join the trio in their Eternal Home.  Mrs. Lomie Hart, 50, who was the mother, grandmother and aunt of the youngsters, died in Mercy Hospital as a result of the third-degree burns suffered in the same fire.  Last rites were held at Grace Memorial Presbyterian Church, with the Rev. Harold R. Tolliver in charge.  He was assisted by the Rev. Charles H. Foggie of Wesley Center AME Zion Church..."

CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, February 13, 1954, pg. 26 reads: "Fellowship Service Slated Sunday - These lay and professional religious leaders were among the members of the Race Relations Commission who assisted in planning the sixth annual Fellowship Service to be held at Soldiers and Sailors Memorial Hall next Sunday afternoon, Feb. 14, beginning at 3:30 o'clock. The service, in observance of Race Relations Sunday, will have Dr. W. J .Faulkner of Chicago as the principal speaker.  Shown here making final arrangements are (seated): Mrs. William T. Poole, general chairman; Roland M. Sawyer and Miss Elizabeth Reed.  Behind them are the Rev. James B. Cayce, the Rev. A.A.Hughey, the Rev. Robert C. Steele and the Rev. S. Amos Brackeen. - Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: Theresa A. Clarke holding Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper with headlines reading "Eartha Kitt in $2 million Suit!" and "2 Pittsburghers Nabbed at Derby," in newsstand in East Liberty station
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 15, 1954, pg. 5, reads: "Courier at Station News Stands - A new service for travelers, commuters and vacationists has been inaugurated with the placing of the Courier on news stands in railroad and bus stations in Pittsburgh. Couriers are also available are available at two news stands in Pennsylvania Station, Greyhound Bus Station, P&LE Station, South Side at Smithfield Street, and East Liberty Station.  The Courier is also available to residents in Pittsburgh at the news stands located at Sixth and Wylie, and the Old Post Office, Fourth and Smithfield.  The Courier is on sale at these places each Thursday afternoon.  Pictured above is Theresa A. Clarke, news stand clerk in East Liberty Station selling a copy of the Courier.  She advises to get your copy early, since they sell very rapidly. - Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: P. L. Prattis wearing Arabian clothing after tour of Middle East, standing in domestic interior with concave mirror and floral curtains
CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper December 25, 1954, pg. 8, reads: "Where Jesus Walked - Percival L. Prattis, Courier executive editor, addressed the Wesley Center morning congregation Sunday, Dec. 19, with a message bearing the impact of his recent study tour of the Holy Lands. The speaker was one of a group of editors and writers who toured Middle Eastern Countries during the month of November through the courtesy of the American Christian Palestine Committee. In colorful native Arabian attire, he impressed fellow church members with a vivid and enlightening account of conditions in the Arab states."

TitMainTitle: Group portrait the Deuces Wild band, from left: Flo Cassinelli on tenor sax, Don Mastri on bass, Bob Negri on piano, and Spider Rondinelli on drums, performing at Crawford Grill No. 2
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 14, 1955, pg. 20, reads: "Grill Two Headliners - The crowd-pleasing Deuces Wild, currently filling Crawford Grill Two, at Elmore and Wylie, with sweet music, will be at the popular spot for the next two weeks. They have played successful engagements at many of the city's top clubs.  Presently they have two crazy records going : "Ultra" and "that's All That Matters to Me."  To be released in near future are "Swat Mist" and "I Want a Little Girl," all on the Moss label.  That's Flo Cassinelli on the tenor sax; Don Mastri, bass; Bob Negri, piano, and Spider Rondinelli, drums. - Harris PHoto."

CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, April 23, 1955, pg. 1, reads: "Crash Kills One - A two-car collision at Frankstown and Lang Avenues early Saturday morning, killed 17-year-old Harold Scott of 7373 Lemington Avenue, Penn Township, and seriously injured Norman R. Allen, 20, right, inset, of 1 East Lemington Avenue, also of Penn Township, and Thomas H. Croom, 27, left inset, of 2600 Wylie Avenue. TitMainTitle: Duquesne University basketball coach Dudley Moore, bride Margaret Ellen Mount Ricketts, groom Richard "Dick" Ricketts, and Duquesne athletic director Lou "Doc" Skender, posed in interior
CatDescriptText:
Cutline for image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 11, 1955, pg. 22, reads:  "A Happy Day - Dick Ricketts, All-American basketball player and one of the greatest athletes ever to matriculate at Duquesne University, was kept busy last week.  First, the 6' 8" athlete signed a contract to play professional basketball for the St. Louis Hawks at a salary said to call for $10,000 a year.  Saturday he was married to his college sweetheart, pretty Margaret Ellen Mount, in Pittsburgh, and Sunday he was graduated from Duquesne.  It's figured Ricketts will sign a baseball contract sometime this week.  He pitches and plays first.  Dandy Dick is shown watching his bride accept congratulations from Lou (Doc) Skender, Duquesne Athletic director and baseball coach.  Dudley Moore, basketball coach, far left, look on approvingly. - Harris Photo."

Cutline for related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 11, 1955, pg. 11, reads:  "Leaving the church - Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. (Dick) Ricketts, smile as they leave the sanctuary of the Epiphany Roman Catholic Church following the ceremony which made them one Saturday, June 4.  Mrs. Ricketts is the former Margaret Ellen Mount, teacher at St. Bernard Parochial School, Mount Lebanon.  The groom's brother David, right, was best man. - Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: Two fire fighters on porch roof of burning house, 1502 Brushton Avenue, Penn Township
CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 29, 1955, pg. 6, reads: "Fire at 1502 Brushton Avenue, Penn Twp...13 lost home in blaze Saturday." Accompanying article reads: "13 Homeless in Penn Twp. Fire - Thirteen persons, including Mr. and Mrs. Robert Whittington, two daughters and sons-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Love and Mr. and Mrs. James Williams, and seven grandchildren lost their home at 1502 Brushton Avenue Saturday morning when fire raged through this house destroying all their possessions.  City firemen and a Penn Township volunteer fire company fought the blaze.  Red Cross officials gave the family a $20 food order, two cots, four blankets, four dozen diapers, outer clothing, and a promise to aid with furniture later.  The families are currently staying at the home of another daughter-in-law, Mrs. Dorothy M. Wynn, 1015 Wheeler Street. - Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: Group portrait of seven women kneeling at altar rail, for National Prayer Day honoring Montgomery Alabama bus boycotters, in St. James AME Church
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, March 31, 1956, pg. 1, reads: "Thousands Observe 'Prayer Day' Here! - In Humble Supplication - As part of nation-wide observance of 'Prayer Day,' March 28, as advocated by Congressman Adam Clayton Powell, members of St. James AME Church gathered to send their prayer petitions up to cleanse racial bias from America's soul and to help the persecuted Montgomery, Ala. bus boycotters endure their ordeal until victory is finally won. - Harris Photo."

CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper January 9, 1960, pg. 20, reads: "Card-O-Rama Committee - Planning the card party, which will be given Jan. 15, 8 P.M., at the Homewood-Brushton YWCA, Kelly St., by the Upland Young Adult Unit of the Urban League, the committee makes final notations on its affair. TitMainTitle: President Dwight D. Eisenhower, speaking at podium in Hunt Armory, another version
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 13, 1956, pg. 2, reads: "The President Speaks - Above is one section of the crowded Hunt Armory where President Eisenhower (inset right) declared on Oct. 9: 'I will not promise that winning a peace based on justice will be cheap and easy.' William P. Young (inset left) is pictured in his plea for election of President Eisenhower and the entire Republican ticket.  Doors were closed at 7:30 P. M. compelling an estimated crowd of 5,000 people to remain outside the Armory to hear the President's nationally televised address at 9 P. M.  The President was introduced by U. S. Senator James H. Duff. - Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: Nurses Joan Fisanich and Carol Feighner standing on either side of Walt Harper lying in hospital bed
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, November 17, 1956, pg. 1, reads: "'Walt' Harper Injured in Car Crash - 'Walt Heard Harps' - So popular bandleader, 'Walt' Harper (center) wisecracked to a Courier reporter, Monday, from a bed in Pittsburgh Hospital, following an auto collision at Dallas and Hamilton Aves. The remark evoked laughter from nurses Joan Fisanich and Carol Feighner. 'Laid out' and 'up,' the maestro managed to retain his sense of humor, despite having been knocked unconscious and suffering injuries to his head, back and knee.  'I heard harps,' he cracked.  'I thought my time was up.' Referring to the $2,000 damage to his Cadillac, right, he jokingly remarked that he had 'now been reduced to a lowly station wagon.'  The car, left, which Harper said 'plowed into mine,' is being lowered by city towing service employes [employees], William Pierce and Albert Clark.  It is owned by John Becker, according to police. - Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: Group portrait of five women, including bride Jeanne Yvonne Adams Daniels wearing long sleeved gown with full skirt, and four men, including groom Joseph W. Daniels, posed in Grace Memorial Presbyterian Church
CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, September 7, 1957, pg. A10, reads: "Mrs. Joseph W. Daniels...lovely bride. - Harris Photo." Portions of accompanying article read: "Charming School Teacher Marries In Impressive Late Summer Nuptials.  One of the late summer season's prettiest weddings was that of Jeanne Yvonne Adams and Joseph Wayne Daniels.  The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lorenzo R. Adams of Pittsburgh; the groom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Daniels Sr. of New Orleans, La.  The Rev. Harold R. Tolliver performed the impressive rites in Grace Memorial Presbyterian Church.  The bride was lovely in a white gown of Cupino Silk.  Her veil of bridal illusion was attached to a hat of pearls and sequins.  She carried a bouquet of white orchids and stephanoti.  The attendants included the bride's two sisters: Miss Mable Adams, maid of honor, and Mrs. Sadie E. Harris as matron of honor.  Bridesmaids were Mrs. Edythe Smith Perkins, Miss Evelyn Donald and Miss Aldora Sanders.  They wore gowns of turquoise and coral rose with matching hats.  They carried colonial bouquets of yellow pom poms and roses.  William Jackson of Baltimore, Md., was the groom's best man.  Ushers were John H. Adams, Arthur Perkins Jr., Burl J. Moone III, and Eugene Barkley of Philadelphia.  Little Laura Gale Adams, niece of eh bride, was flower girl.  Cornelius Harris III, nephew of the bride was ringbearer.  The wedding was directed by Mrs. Nan Moon Currington. .... The bride is a graduate of the University of Pittsburgh and for the past three years has been a member of the faculty of Taylor Allderdice High School.  She completed courses for a master's degree from the University of Pittsburgh this summer.  The groom, a former student at Dillard University, New Orleans, in employed in New York City where the couple will reside. ..."

TitMainTitle: Crowd gathered around M. Lifsher & Son booth with woman wearing rabbit costume handing out items, in Syria Mosque for the 1957 Pittsburgh Courier Home Service Fair
CatDescriptText:
Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, April 6, 1957, pg. 1 reads: "2,000 at Opening Night - A jam-packed crowd of 2,000 persons attended the opening night of The Courier Home Service Fair at Syria Mosque, Tuesday night. Here is shown part of the throng flocked around the New Diamond market booth to receive jars of spaghetti given away by manager Charles Glick to the first 300 women to visit his booth.  The fair, one of the best ever presented in Pittsburgh, will close tonight (Thursday, March 21).  It will  be the biggest prize night of the fair and another capacity crowd is expected. - Harris photo."

TitMainTitle: Group portrait of "Miss Golden Jubilee" contestants, from left: Janice Johnson, Rosalind or Rosalyn King, "queen" Iva Lewis holding scepter, Patty Felgram, and Janet McKittrick, standing on platform in Moreell Park, Aliquippa
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, July 5, 1958, pg. 1, reads: "Queen and Her Court - Lovely Iva Lewis (center) was crowned 'Miss Golden Jubilee' at Moreell Park, Aliquippa, on Monday night. One of 143 contestants when the contest began May 12, the field was reduced to the above five on June 21. Popular Rosalind King, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Oliver King of Aliquippa, ranked fourth when the voting was over.  Left to right" Janice Johnson, fifth; Miss King: the 'Queen'; Patty Felgram, second, and Janet McKittrick, third.  Total vote count was 459,748.  The winner received 86,487 votes.  Second and third place contestants received 77,117 and 75,326 votes respectively.  Miss King won 51,310 votes, while Miss Johnson earned 43,128.  Burgess James Bruno gave the welcome address at the opening celebration, which featured the crowning of the queen and her court. - Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: Wooden staircase entrance to Juicy Plum Club speakeasy behind 1719 Centre Avenue on Roberts Street, Hill District
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper August 30, 1958, pg. 4, reads: "Sin Den Murder Site - During a dispute over the purchase of a drink for a woman, 29-year-old Jonathan Cobbs of 701 Chauncey St., was killed by a stab wound in the chest from a knife in the hands of Raymond Bryant, 30, of Arthur St., early Sunday morning on the porch of the Juicy Plum Club (left photo), a speakeasy, located on the second floor of this building at 1719 Centre Ave. and Roberts St., according to police. Entrance to the steps leading into the club is gained through a doorway in an eight-foot high wooden fence on the Roberts St. side of the building. The right photo shows the Roberts St. side back entrance to the after-hours sin den, with arrow pointing to door and peephole. - Harris Photo."

CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper October 31, 1959, pg. 32, reads: "Rev. Foggie Reappointed - The Rev. Charles H. Foggie, second from right, of Wesley Center AME Zion Church, and president of the Pittsburgh branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, was reappointed to the Housing Authority of the City of Pittsburgh by Mayor Thomas J. Gallagher, seated, Tuesday. Besides Mrs. Foggie, others attending, who are all Authority members were, left to right: Joseph A. Goney, secretary; Atty. Everett E. Utterback, chief legal counsel; Alfred Tronzo, administrator; and Frances Johns, treasurer. The Rev. Mr. Foggie, who has completed five years of service, is assistant to the secretary and the treasurer. - Harris photo."

TitMainTitle: Portrait of Mira Kavaler wearing dark dress with wrap skirt with pleated hem, standing in front of light colored curtain in Holiday House for D. I. Club annual benefit for National Foundation
CatDescriptText:
Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, March 11, 1961, pg. 14A, reads: "D.I.Models who made the annual benefit style show and dance a fascinating evening at Holiday House just outside of Pittsburgh, show the winning ways that turned hundreds of guests into delighted patrons...Mina Kavaler of the Victoria modeling School...The nine hand-picked models showed the famous DuPont collection, which is created each year just for the National Foundation (March of Dimes). The D.I.'s headed by Gay DeHall, have as their sole project the National Foundation, and they plan to sponsor the Ebony Show in September. - Harris Photos"

Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 27, 1961, pg. A10 reads: "Loendi Hostesses - When the good ship Avalon floats down the beautiful Ohio, Memorial Day, for Loendi Club's gala moonlight cruise, the above group of hostesses will be on hand to add additional glamour along with those listed last week.  Top row, left to right: Mira Kavaler, Kathleen Holloway, Barbara Tardy and Gay DeHall.  Bottom row in same order: Gertna Horsley, Marjorie Miller, Dorothy Mellix, Marlene Moore and Esther Ficklin.  Also serving as a hostess although not shown in the picture is Carole Velar. -Harris photos."

TitMainTitle: Group portrait of wedding party with men including Guy Jones, Henry Smith, Earl F. Lloyd, best man Earl Dial, groom Theodore B. Lloyd, women including bride Shirley V. Jeffries Lloyd wearing gown with sheer yoke and elbow length sleeves, matron of honor Bertha Frazier, Alma Anderson, Dora Mae Moore, Thelma Lee McKithen, flower girl Shelia or Sheila Frazier, and ring bearer Carl Jeffries Jr., posed in front of dark background, in Harris Studio, another version
CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, November 10, 1951, pg. 10, reads: "Mrs. Theodore B. Lloyd...weds Dee Cee Man." Portion of accompanying article reads: "Dee Cee Couple Wed in Pittsburgh Church - Pittsburgh - The former Shirley V. Jeffries of Washington D. C., became the bride of Theodore B. Lloyd, son of Mrs. Daisy Lloyd of Washington D. C., during an elaborate double-ring ceremony at Macedonia Baptist Church here recently. The Rev. A. L. Solomon officiated the rites.  A reception followed in lecture room of the church.  The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William I. Jeffries of Cherokee Street, was given in marriage by her father.  She was lovely in a gown of heavy cream satin with a full skirt terminating in a full-length train, the bodice was fashioned with a silk illusion yoke studded with rhinestones and seed pearls. The finger-tipped veil, with a half bonnet style satin cap studded with rhinestones, was designed and made by her cousin, Thelma Lee McKithen.  The bride carried a bouquet of miniature mums and white roses with a pal orchid corsage in the center.  Cousins attend bride.  Mrs. Bertha Frazier, of Washington D. C., was matron of honor, wearing a gown of green marquisette with a matching braided halo.  Bridesmaids were Mrs. Alma Anderson of Washington D. C., Mrs. Dora Mae Moore of Pittsburgh, and Miss Thelma Lee McKithen of Pittsburgh.  All attendants were cousins of the bride.  They were all gowned in identical pastel shades of blue, orchid and peach with matching half hats.  The little flower girl was Shelia Frazier, daughter of Mrs. Martha Frazier, the ring bearer was little Carl Jefries [Jeffries] Jr., of Buffalo, N. Y., nephew of the bride.  Ernest Dial was best man,  Ushers were Guy Jones, Henry Smith and Earl F. Lloyd, the groom's brother who was home on leave from the Army, all of Washington D. C...."

TitMainTitle: Rush Party participants and guests of Alpha Gamma Chi Sorority, from left, floor: Lillian Adams and Elaine Gibson; second row: Elie Steinberg, Thelma Miller, Willa Mae Rice, and Willa Rose; standing: Ann Robinson, Erma Petett, Barbara James, Melusena Carl, Palestine Zellares, and Dorothy Kendrick, gathered in interior
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 2, 1953, pg. 12, reads: "Sorors In 'Tuneful Togs' - Some of the sorors and guests attending the Rush Party given by Alpha Gamma Chapter of Alpha Gamma Chi Sorority, April 25, pose in togs which represent tunes. On the floor: Lillian Adams, left depicts 'Schooldays'; Elaine Gibson 'Dance Ballerina Dance.'  Second row, left to right, Elie Steinberg and Thelma Miller are a 'Mexican Hat Dance team,' Willa Mae Rice, sponsor, sports her 'Easter Bonnet,' and Willa Rose 'Sweet Violets.'  Standing, left to right: Ann Robinson is costumed for 'Carmen'; Erma Petett for "Don't Let the Stars Get in Your Eyes"; Barbara James wears a 'Gray Bonnet with Blue Ribbon on it,' and Melusena Carl has 'Buttons and Bows' all over.  Palestine Zellares and Dorothy Kendricks are not in costume.  Soror Elaine Gibson was party hostess.  Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: Groom Cordell Lee wearing moustache and light colored bow tie, and bride Barbara Jane Edwards Lee wearing short sleeved lace wedding dress, and elbow length fingerless gloves, holding bouquet of flowers, walking down aisle of Park Place AME Church, Homestead
CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 15, 1955, pg. 11, reads: "HONEYMOONING - Mr. and Mrs. Cordell Lee, principals of a beautiful fall wedding at Park Place AME Church, Saturday, Sept. 24, are honeymooning in East. The bride, nee Barbara Jane Edwards, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Edwards of Munhall, Pa.  The groom is a U. S. Naval officer. - Harris Photo."  Article reads: Edwards - Lee Nuptials Are Brilliant Season's Event - In a cathedral gown of alencon lace and peau de sole, Barbara Jane Edwards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Edward of Munhall, Pa., became the bride of U.S. Navy Officer Cordell Lee, Saturday, Sept. 24, at Park Place AME Church, HOmestead, Pa., with the Rev. C. E. Drummer officiating.  A beaded lace cap held her fingertip illusion veil.  The bride carried a bouquet of white orchids and calla lilies.  Christian Dior gowns of nylon crystalette, and velvet in emerald green, blush pink, and gold were chosen by the bride's attendants.  Mrs. Marion Burgess was her sister's matron of honor.  Bridesmaids were Mmes. Juanita Matthews and Thelma Fleming of Washington, D.C.; Nora Morante and Ethel Terry.  The bride's niece, Debbie Gay Evans, was flower girl.  Best man - Fulmore Lauer was his nephew's best man.  Ushers were Lonnie Peay, Bernard Irvin, Harry Burgess and George Evans.  Washington D. C., guest here for the ceremony were Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Murray, Sgt. and Mrs. James Tillman, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Larrance, Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Dawson, Mmes Clyde Johnson, Connie Cook, Lillian Ruffin, Margaret Kelley, Misses Lucy Bankett, Ida Moore, Messrs. John Higgs and Harold Curry.  Other out-of-towners were Mrs. Ann Garnett Green or New York, Richard Harvey of New Jersey, and Harold Caldwell of Cleveland, Ohio."

TitMainTitle: Group portrait of girl and boy, possibly best man James Johnson, groom Emanuel E. Thompson, bride Betty Lou Carter Thompson wearing floral gown and hennin, and possibly maid of honor Jacqueline Merchant, posed possibly in home at Waring Court, vertical format
CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 16, 1953, pg. 5, reads: "Mrs. Emanuel E. Thompson...Saturday's bride - Carter - Thompson Wedding - Betty Lou Carter, lovely daughter of Mrs. Myrtle Warren became the bride of Emanuel E. Thompson, son of Mrs. and Mrs. Glenn Thompson of Cliff Street, Saturday, May 2, at the home of her grandparents in Waring Court. The Rev. Jesse Moore, associate pastor of Central Baptist Church, officiated.  The bride is a former student of Wilberforce University and the groom is a veteran of Korea.  Beautiful Gown.  She wore a ballerina-length nylon tulle gown with a fitted bodice sprinkled with rhinestones.  Her unusual headpiece was a Fifteenth Century Renaissance crocheted cap, also sprinkled with rhinestones, attached to a fingertip-length veil edged with Chantilly lace.  She carried a white Bible pinned with an orchid.  Jacqueline Merchant, her maid of honor, wore a rose nylon net gown and had a corsage of American Beauty roses. Best man was James Johnson, a boyhood friend of the groom.  Lucille Jones directed the wedding, which was followed by a reception at Union Hall."
