CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 22, 1953, pg. 11 reads: "Marriage Announced - Mr. and Mrs. John B. Lyons announce the marriage of their daughter, Frances, to Albert T. Brown, which took place on Saturday, Aug. 15, at 1:30, in church of the Holy Cross, with the Rev. Samuel D. Rudder, officiating. Mrs. Theodore Witcher, sister of the bride was the matron of honor, while Alex Brown, the groom's brother, served as best man.  He is the son of Mrs. Fanny Brown.  The bride is a teacher in the A. Leo Weil School, and Mr. Brown is employed at the Arbuthnot Stevenson Company, and is the senior warden at Holy Cross Church.  Following a honeymoon trip to New York, the couple will reside at 7200 Hermitage Street. - Harris Photo."

They demanded Tuesday that the city take steps to put up stop signs and lights.  Right: Curtis Williams, leader, second from left, tells a group of citizens that promises have been won from "higher-ups" and protection will be given.  Motorcycle policemen began patrolling the street... throng promised to disperse.  Nearly a score... been tagged to date for speeding. - Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: Group portrait of two boys, and girl wearing dark pegged pants and light colored sailor style top, posed in interior with sampler on wall inscribed "To a Friend's House the Road is Never Long," possibly guests at wedding of Ethel Hurst Mahoney and Raymond B. Mahoney
CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 17, 1959, pg. A14, reads: "Mrs. Raymond B. Mahoney... in stunning ceremony. - Harris Photo." Accompanying article reads: "Hurst - Mahoney Rites in Pittsburgh. A wedding of much charm and beauty was held at St. James AME Church recently, when the Rev. Augustus Sumpter united in marriage, Miss Ethel Hurst, daughter of Mrs. Inez E. Hurst, of Pittsburgh, and Thomas J. Hurst St., of Fort Wayne, Ind., and Raymond B. Mahoney, son of Mrs. Robert Mahoney.  The bride, given in marriage by her father, wore an exquisite ballerina-length gown of eggshell silk taffeta, embellished with appliqued lace medallions and pallettes.  A shoulder-length veil and matching mitts completed her elegant outfit. She carried yellow roses.  Mrs. Christine Seals of Fort Wayne, Ind. sister of the bride, was matron of honor.  Bridesmaid were Mrs. Julia Gaines of Pittsburgh, and Mrs. Fannie Wagstaff of Fort Wayne, other sisters of the bride, and Mrs. Kathleen Hurst and Mrs. Euzee Mahoney.  Mrs. Seals wore apple green and the maids wore apricot chiffon and satin created on simple, yet stunning lines.  Miss Jacqueline Seals was junior bridesmaid.  Little Karen Hurst was a delightful flower girl, and Eric (Rickey) Poole was ring bearer, carrying the real wedding bands on a satin pillow.  Robert Mahoney served his brother as best man, while ushers included: Robert Lavelle, Harry Moore, Charles Palmer, and Theodore Steward.  Mrs. Elizabeth Youngue was the soloist.  Mrs. Mary McEinheimer directed the wedding.  Aides included: Mmes. Ethel Moore, Lucille Cuthbert, Hallie Turner, Marie Simmons, "Kitten" Irvis, Eloise Page, Wilnette Young, Margaret Jane Smith, Gladys Stanton, Jeanne Poole, Adah Lavelle, Margaret Terry, Jeannette Davis, Jean Bolden Parish, Alice Woodruff and Miss Alma Thompson....The newlyweds moved into their new home on Dreary [Deary] St., Pittsburgh, following a brief honeymoon in Cleveland."

TitMainTitle: James Strothers, seated next to birthday cake, surrounded by family members, left to right: Cobren Atkinson, William Brim, Mrs. B.R.Hairston, Carolyn Atkinson, Willie Brim, Mary Brim, daughter, Rev. J.C. Hairston, and Estelle Harrell, gathered in Sixth Mt. Zion Baptist Church for 100th birthday party
CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 6, 1961, pg. 16 reads: "Centenarian - James Strothers, faithful member of Sixth Mt. Zion Baptist Church, Pittsburgh, celebrated his 100th birthday on April 23 by attending Sunday school in his usual way. He has been a member of Sixth Mt. Zion since 1945.  Mr. Strothers was born at Criglyville, Va., in 1861.  He came to Pittsburgh in 1887 and joined the Mt. Ararat Baptist Church in 1915.  He has one daughter, Mrs. Mary  Brim, and seven grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren.  Left to right: Cobren Atkinson, great-granddaughter; William Brim, grandson; Carolyn Atkinson, granddaughter; Willie Brim, son-in-law; Mrs. Brim, daughter; Mrs. B.R.Hairston (rear), Sunday school superintendent; Rev. J.C. Hairston, pastor; Mrs. Estelle Harrell and Mr. Strothers, seated. - Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: Wrecked Chevy station wagon bent in half, parked in lot with other automobiles and fence, brick buildings with windows in background
CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, September 21, 1963, pg. 3 reads: "Death Car - Three men died in above station wagon after the driver, resenting racial slurs by a white motorist, took off in pursuit across the 31st Street Bridge, smashed head-on into a car coming in the opposite direction and then smashed into a curb, police said. The vehicle immediately burst into flame. - Harris Photo."

TitMainTitle: Jacqueline Farrell and Michele Jones wearing "Bill Scranton" sashes, standing on either side of Robert Mosely or Mosley, in front of tiled wall at Republican rally at Civic Arena
CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, November 3, 1962, pg. 18, reads: "Ike Drew the People, Their Attention, Cheers - Main speaker at the GOP rally last week was former President Eisenhower. For the occasion, a gala program was planned.  Among participants were, left photo, Robert Mosley, who sang the "Star Spangled Banner" and led the audience in Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.  He is flanked by two of the "Beauties for Scranton," Jacqueline Farrell, left and Michele Jones... - Harris Photos."
